text: In the MTK overload of `DiffEqBase.ODEFunction` the observed equations will be injected into another  constructor for `ODEFunction`. This happens <https://github.com/SciML/ModelingToolkit.jl/blob/805811b9ef2da00c3fa5f7460ebf61ecfc1bd9cb/src/systems/diffeqs/abstractodesystem.jl#L174|here>. In which of the many DiffEq packages is this constructor defined? I’d like to hook into the observed mechanism from a “classical” diffeq system (without MTK) to make some algebraic states accessible from the solution.

text: <@U01BYANF42K> Are you maybe looking for this? <https://github.com/SciML/SciMLBase.jl/blob/d58e550f1b73ad8147b98288d0cc0ae276ab0333/src/scimlfunctions.jl#L418>

elements.text: Are you maybe looking for this?

text:
No problem! For reference, you can find it by doing something like:
```julia> using DiffEqBase

julia> methods(DiffEqBase.ODEFunction)
# 3 methods for type constructor:
[1] ODEFunction(f::ODEFunction; kwargs...) in SciMLBase at C:\Users\Dan\.julia\packages\SciMLBase\Afx1r\src\scimlfunctions.jl:504
[2] ODEFunction(sys::ModelingToolkit.AbstractODESystem, args...; kwargs...) in ModelingToolkit at C:\Users\Dan\.julia\packages\ModelingToolkit\0BgwD\src\systems\diffeqs\abstractodesystem.jl:107
[3] ODEFunction(f; kwargs...) in SciMLBase at C:\Users\Dan\.julia\packages\SciMLBase\Afx1r\src\scimlfunctions.jl:503```
